misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Execution Order / Using Variables Before Reading Input
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes the program can calculate the result using the variables’ initial values (0.0) and then later read user input without needing to recompute the result.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, statements execute top-to-bottom. Assigning new values to variables after a calculation does not retroactively update earlier computed results. If you compute `finalDrivingCost` before calling `nextDouble()`, you are computing with the default 0.0 values, so the printed cost remains 0.0 unless you recalculate after input.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output (always prints $0.0 for normal inputs).

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Misunderstanding Variable Copying (Temporary Variables Stay in Sync)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes the 'temporary' variables will reflect later changes to the original input variables, or that copying initial values into new variables is necessary for clarity but still connected to the originals.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Primitive doubles are copied by value. `temporaryMilesPerGallon` etc. are independent variables; updating `milesPerGallonInput` later does not change `temporaryMilesPerGallon`. Because the temporaries are set before input is read, they remain 0.0 throughout, leading to an incorrect computation.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Temporal Ordering Misconception - Calculation Before Input
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that variables can be assigned and used in calculations before the user provides input values. They think that declaring variables with initial values and performing calculations on them will work correctly, even though the input prompts come after the calculation block.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student has a flawed mental model of program execution flow. They don't understand that code executes sequentially from top to bottom, and that using variables before they receive actual user input means they still contain their default values (0.0). The student appears to think that the calculation block and the input prompts are somehow decoupled or can be reordered logically without affecting the result. In reality, the calculation of `finalDrivingCost` happens with all three input variables still set to 0.0, before the user ever enters any values.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output - the program will always output 0.0 as the cost, regardless of user input, because the cost is calculated before any input is read.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that by assigning a variable to another (e.g., temporaryDrivingDistanceMiles = drivingDistanceMilesInput), they have created a permanent, reactive link. They assume that when drivingDistanceMilesInput is updated via the Scanner later in the code, the dependent 'temporary' variables and the 'finalDrivingCost' calculation will automatically update to reflect the new values.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Java is an imperative language with sequential execution. Assignments copy the current value of the right-hand side into the left-hand side variable at a specific point in time. There is no 'live' link between variables; once an assignment or calculation is performed, its result is stored in memory and does not change unless a new assignment is explicitly executed.

evidence.code_snippet: double temporaryDrivingDistanceMiles = drivingDistanceMilesInput;
double temporaryGallonsUsed = temporaryDrivingDistanceMiles / temporaryMilesPerGallon;
drivingDistanceMilesInput = userInputScanner.nextDouble();

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the order of logic in the source code does not strictly define the order of execution. They think they can define the mathematical 'plan' or formula for the calculation at the top of the main method and have it apply to data that is collected at the bottom of the method.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student fails to realize that the Java Virtual Machine executes statements line-by-line from top to bottom. Because the calculation logic (lines 22-31) occurs before the user input is captured (lines 34-45), the calculation uses the initial default values of 0.0 and never runs again after the inputs are actually provided.

evidence.code_snippet: if (temporaryMilesPerGallon != 0.0) {
System.out.println("The cost of driving is $" + finalDrivingCost);

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Thinking copied variables update automatically (value vs reference confusion)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that assigning `temporaryDrivingDistanceMiles = drivingDistanceMilesInput` (and similar) creates a link, so when `drivingDistanceMilesInput` is later read from the user, the `temporary...` variables (and the earlier cost calculation) will somehow reflect the new values automatically.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, primitive types like `double` are copied by value. `temporaryDrivingDistanceMiles`, `temporaryMilesPerGallon`, and `temporaryPricePerGallon` keep the values they had at assignment time (here, all `0.0`) and do not change when the original variables change later. Also, expressions are evaluated when executed; earlier calculations do not “re-run” after inputs are read.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: the program prints a driving cost of `$0.0` for any nonzero input values.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes the program can compute the cost before collecting input, or that the cost will be computed later even though the code appears earlier.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Java executes statements sequentially from top to bottom. Here, `finalDrivingCost` is computed while all inputs are still `0.0`, and it is never recomputed after reading the actual user inputs.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: cost is computed using default zeros and remains unchanged when inputs are later read.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that as long as variables are declared and updated at some point in the program, they can be used in calculations that appear earlier in the code. They think that performing a calculation before prompting for input is acceptable because the input will eventually be provided, and somehow the calculation will retroactively use those values.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student does not understand that Java executes statements sequentially in the order they appear in the source code. When a calculation is performed on line 18-27, it uses the current values of the variables at that moment (all 0.0). Updating those variables later (lines 29-37) does not cause the already-executed calculation to re-run or change. The student confuses the declaration/initialization phase with the execution phase—they seem to think that values can be 'pulled in' later, rather than understanding that each statement executes exactly once when reached.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: The program outputs 'The cost of driving is $0.0' instead of the expected result like '$34.297872340425535'. The calculation completes before any user input is obtained, so it always uses 0.0 for all three values.

evidence.code_snippet: double temporaryDrivingDistanceMiles = drivingDistanceMilesInput;

System.out.print("Enter the driving distance in miles: ");
        drivingDistanceMilesInput = userInputScanner.nextDouble();

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that assigning a variable to a formula involving other variables creates a live, reactive link. They expect that when 'drivingDistanceMilesInput' or 'milesPerGallonInput' are updated by the user later in the program, the 'finalDrivingCost' variable will automatically recalculate its value to reflect these changes, similar to how a spreadsheet cell works.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Java is an imperative language where assignment is an immediate operation. An expression is evaluated exactly once using the current state of variables. To reflect updated values, the calculation must be explicitly re-executed after the inputs are received.

evidence.code_snippet: double temporaryDrivingDistanceMiles = drivingDistanceMilesInput;
double temporaryGallonsUsed = temporaryDrivingDistanceMiles / temporaryMilesPerGallon;
finalDrivingCost = temporaryGallonsUsed * temporaryPricePerGallon;

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the logical structure of the program (the 'how' of the calculation) can be defined at the start of the main method regardless of whether the necessary data is currently available. They assume the program will 'wait' to finalize the calculation until the values used in the logic are provided by the user.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Java programs execute instructions in a strict top-to-bottom sequence. Data must be read and stored in variables before those variables can be used in mathematical operations. The student has placed the calculation logic before the input statements, meaning the calculation occurs when all values are still 0.0.

evidence.code_snippet: drivingDistanceMilesInput = userInputScanner.nextDouble();
System.out.println("The cost of driving is $" + finalDrivingCost);
